Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC FRP: Collaborative Research: Fundamental Research in Visualization-based Gap Analysis and Link Prediction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed Visualization-Based Gap Analysis effort is aimed at providing an intuitive visualization and analysis techniques to provide analysts with the ability to understand what has happened within a domain, comprehend its current status and operations, and explore the impact of changes to the system. Link
Discovery is seeking to automatically predict what relations arise in the future between objects. The proposed research intends to reformulate the link discovery problem to include predicting the strength of the link as well as create techniques to detect and predict special categories of future links; such links that arise that bridge two dense clusters of objects. Link prediction for domains other than social media and specialized literature domains will be explored.

Predictive analysis to determine future events in an industry environment based on current and past data represents an outcome of tremendous economic and societal impact. Through establishment of more rigorous capabilities for Visual Gap Analysis and Link Discovery, industry may be better able to understand what has happened, comprehend what is the current state, and obtain some grasp of what is likely to happen, may be greatly enhanced increasing productivity and allowing focus on problem resolution. The proposed effort is supported by the Industry Advisory Board and will engage individual center members. Graduate students will be trained through the research and results will be integrated into courses and industry seminars and short courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The collaborative effort between Drexel University (Drexel) and the University of Louisiana at Lafayette (UL Lafayette) was designed to enhance two complimentary approaches in graph analytics: link discovery and visualization-based gap analysis. Link discovery seeks to predict what links (relationships) will form between nodes (entities) in the future that are not currently present and to predict which currently existing links will disappear. Visualization-based gap analysis seeks to provide tools to visually present the data, and along with underlying analytical models, allow users to understand what has happened within a domain, comprehend the current status, and explore the impact of changes to the current system (graph). Ideally, link discovery would allow us to predict what changes will occur, in terms of links, and the visualization-based gap analysis would allow users to understand the impacts of those changes.

Drexel led the visualization-based gap analysis research and UL Lafayette led the link discovery resea. With respect to the visualization-based gap analysis effort, Drexel  accomplished three major goals. First, We follow anagnostopolus et al's approach to identify social influence in the socail network from two other sources, homophily and confounding. We analyze the information passing in an online recommendation system.We proposed a Semi-Supervised Dirichlet-Hawkes Process (SDHP) to deal with topic detec- tion and tracking from social media. SDHP can handle topic detection from short messages efficiently;  track topics from continuous mes- sage stream without time granularity definition requirement. The other major goal is related to missing protein-protein link prediction. The most interesting and possibly the most useful application of hierarchical random graphs is the prediction of missing interactions in networks in which the available information is incomplete as in the case of protein-protein interaction data, especially in our case of studying protein translation regulatory networks
